title: How to Season Chicken Fajitas

methods.name: Applying Quick and Easy Seasoning Blend or Dry Seasonings

steps.headline: Combine all of your dry spices in a large mixing bowl.
steps.description: Portion out 2 tablespoons (36 g) of chili powder, 1 teaspoon (6 g) of salt, 1 teaspoon (6 g) of paprika, ½ teaspoon (3 g) of garlic powder, ½ teaspoon (3 g) of cayenne pepper, ½ teaspoon (3 g) of ground cumin, and ½ tsp (3 g) of onion powder. Stir the spices together until they're thoroughly mixed. You can use more or less of each ingredient as desired to suit your tastes. To prevent clumps, make sure you do your mixing with a clean, dry fork or spoon.

steps.headline: Incorporate any other herbs or spices you wish to include.
steps.description: If you want to dress up your seasoning blend a little, consider adding other ingredients like oregano, paprika, coriander, or onion powder. Flavors like these can lend even more depth to your finished fajitas. Shake in roughly 1-1½ teaspoon (6-9 g) of each additional seasoning, or simply add them to taste. Mixing a tablespoon of cornstarch in with your dry spices can help them form a thicker coating.

steps.headline: Toss the chicken in your seasoning blend.
steps.description: Add your pre-thawed, sliced chicken to the mixing bowl. Shake the bowl gently to sift the chicken through the seasoning, or use a fork to turn the pieces individually. When you're done, your chicken strips should be covered in a thin layer of seasoning. The thinner you slice your chicken, the better the seasoning will stick.

steps.headline: Apply additional seasoning once you begin cooking.
steps.description: For even more intense flavor, sprinkle a little extra seasoning onto your chicken while it's sizzling in the skillet. You can also do the same for your peppers, onions, and other veggies to guarantee that every bite tastes just as good as the one before it. This can also be a good way to help make up for any seasoning that happens to rub off during the cooking process. Alternatively, finish preparing your fajitas like normal, then make your remaining seasoning available once it's time to serve them up. That way, everyone can enjoy their preferred level of spice.

steps.headline: Combine your oil and citrus juice in a large mixing bowl.
steps.description: Drizzle in 2–3 tablespoons (30–44 mL) of extra virgin olive or canola oil and 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of either lemon or lime juice. Whisk the liquids together until they form a loose suspension. For the best flavor, use fresh lemons or limes rather than a from-concentrate juice. Let the fruit reach room temperature and roll them against the countertop a few times to extract more juice from them. This recipe doesn’t produce a large quantity of marinade—you really just need enough to coat the chicken prior to cooking.

steps.headline: Stir in your dry spices.
steps.description: Once you’ve combined the oil and citrus juice, shake in 1-1½ teaspoons (6-9 g) each of garlic powder, cumin, cayenne pepper, and chili powder or chili flakes. Feel free to adjust the amount of each spice to your own personal preferences. Whisk the mixture thoroughly. It’s always best to season dishes like fajitas to taste. If you need some general guidelines to follow, however, aim to add 1-1½ teaspoons (6-9 g) of each spice. You can also use ordinary salt and pepper in place of any of these spices if they don't suit your tastes.

steps.headline: Incorporate any other dry spices you wish to include.
steps.description: If you want to dress up your marinade a little, consider adding seasonings like oregano, paprika, coriander, or onion powder. These sorts of ingredients can be used to lend even more depth to the flavor of your finished fajitas. Use 1-1½ teaspoons (6-9 g) of each additional spice.

steps.headline: Coat your chicken in your homemade marinade.
steps.description: Add the uncooked chicken to your mixing bowl, turning each piece over 2-3 times to make sure the marinade sticks to all sides. When you’re done, cover the bowl with a sheet of plastic cling wrap.Tip: Juicy, meaty cuts like breasts and thighs are perfect for grilling and slicing. Make sure you get the boneless variety to cut down on your prep time.

steps.headline: Allow the chicken to marinate in the refrigerator for 1-4 hours.
steps.description: Place the seasoned chicken on one of the central shelves in your refrigerator and let it sit for at least an hour before you begin cooking. The longer you let your chicken marinate, the bolder the flavor will be. Set a timer or keep a close eye on the clock so you’ll know when your chicken is ready to come out of the refrigerator. As the chicken marinates, the acid in the lemon or lime juice will not only infuse a bright, tangy taste, but also help tenderize the meat.

steps.headline: Sauté bell peppers and onion together.
steps.description: When you’re ready to begin cooking your fajitas, be sure to heat your sliced peppers and onions in the same skillet before putting in the chicken. Their earthy and aromatic notes will mingle to balance out the smoky, spicy, zesty flavors of the various seasonings you used. Try adding some quartered ripe tomatoes or thinly-sliced portobello mushrooms for a healthier and more colorful take on classic fajita veggies.Tip: You only need to cook your veggies for 3-5 minutes, just long enough to crisp them up and unlock their full flavor. Any longer than that and they could become mushy.

steps.headline: Throw in some jalapeños to spice things up.
steps.description: Slice 1-2 peppers and stir them in with your other veggies while they’re sizzling away. Don’t forget to remove the seeds first, though—they’re the hottest part of the pepper, which means you could end up with more burn than you bargained for if you’re not careful! Fresh jalapeños will offer plenty of kick for spice lovers. If you only want a little bite, grab a jar of pre-sliced pickled jalapeños instead. Serrano, pasilla, or fresno peppers can also make a unique substitute for jalapeños.

steps.headline: Sprinkle grated cheese onto your finished fajitas.
steps.description: Monterey Jack, sharp cheddar, and asadero are all popular choices for serving with Mexican cuisine. For a more traditional take, try crumbly cotija or rich queso fresco, both of which will also add an extra hint of saltiness. Be sure to add your cheese while your fajitas are hot to get make sure it gets nice and melty. You can find a wide selection of cheeses from all over the world at most specialty grocery stores.

steps.headline: Top your fajitas with a dollop of guacamole, salsa, or pico de gallo.
steps.description: The cool creaminess of guacamole will help offset the piquancy of the chicken and veggies. Similarly, salsa and pico de gallo can be used to play up the tanginess of your fajitas and tie all of the individual flavors together. If time permits, whip up your own guacamole, salsa, or pico de gallo. These items are delicious, easy to make, and taste far better than their store-bought counterparts.

steps.headline: Add a dash of hot sauce to turn up the heat even more.
steps.description: Slather your toppings with an all-purpose sauce like Tabasco or Texas Pete, or choose a Mexican favorite like Cholula, Tapatío, or El Yucateco if you’re looking for something more authentic. Enjoy! There are all sorts of hot sauces out there ranging from mild (standard chili pepper-based sauces) to blazing (habañero, scorpion, and ghost pepper concoctions). Find one that complements both the flavors of your fajitas and your preferred heat level. Hot sauce can be used in addition to or in place of condiments like salsa and pico de gallo.
